NewsLines.HeadLine: Soccer-South American round-up

body.p: By Brian Homewood

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Chile's championship got back to normal at the weekend after players ended a three-week long strike which had forced two rounds of matches to be postponed and youth teams to be fielded last week.

Colombia's veteran goalkeeper Rene Higuita was given a rapturous reception by fans of his former club Atletico Nacional as he returned to his old hunting ground with Pereira, the team where he is making his latest comeback attempt.

Argentine strikers continued to knock in the goals around the continent. Luis Bonnet was on target for Sporting Cristal in Peru, where he is leading scorer, and Cristian Carnero added two more to his tally in Ecuador, helping championship leaders Deportivo Quito keep their unbeaten record.
There was no football at the weekend in Uruguay or Paraguay, where the championships took a break.
CHILE
Chile's players returned to action at the weekend after calling off a 23-day long strike, in which they protested over unpaid wages and demanded a greater say in the administration of the sport.

The stoppage caused two weekends of football to be postponed, while last weekend's matches went ahead with youth teams. Despite protests from the professional players, the results of last weekend's matches have stood.

Cobreloa maintained a 100 percent record in the Clausura championship by hammering Santiago Morning 4-0 away. Uruguayan Osvaldo Canobbio and Jose Luis Diaz put Cobreloa two goals ahead in a quarter of an hour, then Mauricio Dinamarca and Ruben Castillo added two more in the last 30 minutes.
The team from the copper mining town of Calama, who have enjoyed a new lease of life under former Chile coach Nelson Acosta, have 18 points from six games.
Colo Colo, declared bankrupt at the start of the year, came from behind to beat Audax Italiano 2-1.
Luis Ignacio Quinteros and Manuel Neira scored after Felipe Gonzalez had fired the visitors ahead with a free kick.
COLOMBIA
Veteran goalkeeper Rene Higuita, who is making his latest comeback attempt with Pereira, was given a rapturous welcome by fans of Atletico Nacional, the club where he spent most of his career.
Higuita made several saves as Pereira, one from bottom in the 18-team championship, battled for a 2-2 draw against one of the title contenders.

Afterwards, the Pereira changing-room was mobbed with admirers trying to catch a glimpse of the charismatic 36-year-old, famous for his forays upfield and eccentricities such as the "scorpion kick" save he made against England in a friendly at Wembley.
"I'm happy to be doing what I enjoy most, which is to play football," he said.
Thirteen-times champions Millonarios were beaten 3-2 by Santa Fe in a thrilling Bogota derby, a result which left them bottom of the table. They have not won in their last nine matches.

Aldo Ramirez gave Santa Fe a 2-0 lead with two long-range efforts and Lucas Jaramillo made it 3-0 with 15 minutes to go. Millonarios battled back through Alexander Lemus and Omar Guerra in a thrilling finale which ended with all 22 players in the Santa Fe end of the field.
Oscar Quintabina gave leaders Deportivo Cali a 1-0 win away to relegation-threatened Real Cartagena and surprise package Pasto stayed second by winning 2-0 at Tolima.
Pablo Jaramillo opened the scoring after 40 seconds and Jairo Patino's penalty made sure of three points.
BOLIVIA

Blooming, coached by former Argentina international defender Jose Luis Brown who scored in the 1986 World Cup final, kept their lead in the second stage (Clausura) with a 3-1 win over struggling Mariscal Braun.

Brazilian Clemilson da Silva gave the visitors a surprise first-half lead but Blooming hit back with three goals in nine minutes after the break -- two from Marcelo Ceballos and one from Raul Gutierrez.
Second-placed Bolivar did not play and dropped four points behind but have two games in hand.
They were caught by Real Potosi, who came from two goals behind to beat The Strongest 3-2 with Sandro Lopez scoring twice in the last seven minutes.
The match was played at over 4,000 metres above sea level in the historic silver mining town of Potosi.

Teenage striker Jose Alfredo Castillo scored his 31st goal of the season to give defending champions Oriente Petrolero a 1-0 win away to Independiente Petrolero in Sucre. But Oriente remained seven points behind Blooming in seventh place.
PERU
Argentine Luis Bonnet continued his prolific goalscoring form, hitting the target again in Sporting Cristal's 3-0 win over bottom-of-the-table Juan Aurich.
Brazilian defender Denis and striker Sergio Junior were the other scores for the Brewers, who extended their lead in the second stage of the championship to seven points.
Bonnet has scored 11 goals in as many games in the second stage and 21 in the whole season.

Alianza Lima and Alianza Atletico, two of the chasing teams, spoiled each other's chances of catching Sporting by drawing 2-2. It was the first meeting of the pair since a match in July when the teams refused to take doping tests and each had three points deducted.

Sergio Ibarra, another Argentine, scored a late equaliser for Alianza Atletico after two goals in four minutes from Cristian Garcia and Johan Fano had put Lima ahead. Roberto Garcia had opened the scoring in the first half.

Universitario, who won the first stage but then had to disband their team because of financial difficulties, continued their miserable run, losing 1-0 to Melgar who had not previously won in the second stage. Mexican Roberto Clemente scored the winner for the team from Arequipa.
ECUADOR
Deportivo Quito stayed unbeaten after 15 games in the championship's second stage but threw away a two-goal lead in their 2-2 draw away to struggling police club Espoli.
Argentine Cristian Carnero, who took his tally to 18 and is the competition's leading scorer, put Deportivo in control as he scored twice. He missed a penalty in between.
But the home team hit back in the last 20 minutes with two goals by Claudio Demaria, the second another penalty.
Deportivo lead the second stage, four points ahead of second-placed El Nacional who missed a chance to close the gap when they were held 1-1 at home by Aucas.
Defending champions Emelec continued their revival under new coach Rodolfo Motta.
The Electrics beat Liga de Quito 3-1 with goals by defender Augusto Poroso and midfielders Otilino Tenorio and Moises Cuero and climbed to sixth.
VENEZUELA
Caracas FC stayed top of the Apertura, the first stage of the championship, with a 1-0 win over Nacional Tachira, last season's champions. David McInitosh scored the only goal in the second half.
Argentine striker Matias Milozzi, the championship's top scorer, struck his seventh goal in as many games for Trujillanos but his side still lost 2-1 to Deportivo Tachira, who went second.
Didier Sanabria and Jose Felix Gutierrez scored for Deportivo.
